dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD SLOAN, lies in bed, staring anxiously up at the ceil His wife, MELANIE, is asleep beside him. Moonlight illuminates the room. It is deathly silent, then we HEAR NARRATOR's voice.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad was lying in bed at 3AM wondering why he felt so anxious. CLOSE ON BRAD as his mind wanders from thought to thought

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He scanned through all the possible sources of his dread - as there were many - until he seized upon the Architectural Digest. Brad winces as his memory is stirred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEN PEOPLE are gathered in a living room, drinking and chatting.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: That night, he and Melanie had gone to a dinner party with some of her co-workers. Brad spots an ARCHITECTURAL DIGEST on the coffee table. H notices the cover and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: ON ARCHITECTURAL DIGEST
dialogues.text: Photos of some sleek modern house.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: There was a photo spread of a hideous steel and glass monstrosity in Los Angeles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 2

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The page flips. The owner of the house, NICK and his LATI BOYFRIEND sit on the couch, grinning, in one of the photo

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad realized the home belonged to a college friend, Nick Pascale. ON BRAD - he grimaces at the photo - a stricken look.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The article stated he bought the house for nine million dollars and put another two into it. BACK AND CLOSER ON PHOTO OF NICK AND HIS HUSBAND.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad knew Nick had become successful, but felt gut-punched nonetheless. Brad tosses down the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the other GUESTS, including Melanie, laugh and chat, B glumly stares into space.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: This ruined the dinner party for Brad. He stared into space mostly. GLIMPSES of the other DINNER GUESTS, talking and eating.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He realized the other people at the table were mediocrities. Underachieving beta males, living in Sacramento, a secondary market. Guys thinking they were big fish in the most inconsequential of ponds. Brad looks around at the others with a sour expression.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He felt contempt for himself and everyone there.  BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 3 INT. BRAD’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 5 Brad rolls over in bed, restless and agitated. He picks u his cell phone on the side table. It GLOWS to life.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad’s mind went to other successes that pained him.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHONE
dialogues.text: We SEE Brad’s finger scroll across a SERIES of GOOGLE IMA of Craig Fisher - a political wonk and talking head. Crai in a studio, posing with the President, getting interview

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: There was Craig Fisher - who had worked for the White House. He had written two successful books and was always on TV. He had always been a self-confident know-it-all and now life had affirmed his delusions of grandeur. We now SEE Brad’s fingers ZOOM in close on a PHOTO of Cra his WIFE and TWO DAUGHTERS all smiles, at an event. ON BRAD - illuminated by the light of the phone, he grima He puts the phone down. He looks back up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He thought about Jason Hatfield...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JASON HATFIELD walks with TWO EXECS. An attractive ASSIST intercepts him and they hop in the back of a waiting SUV.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: ..+-whose hedge fund had made him obscenely wealthy. That he was a nice guy who was a philanthropist and had even given money to Brad's non-profit somehow made it even worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tan BILLY WERSTLER sits on the beach with TWO YOUNG SUR GIRLS, chatting them up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 4

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And Billy Werstler who had made enough money from his tech start-up to retire in Maui before he was even forty. INT. BRAD’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 Brad grits his teeth, his mind reeling.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Everyone had won the lottery but him. Bitter adrenaline pumped through Brad’s body. He was never going to get back to sleep. INT. BRAD’S LIVING ROOM - DAY 9 Brad's son, TROY, age six, is playing something for him o electric keyboard. Brad looks over at... ...THE TV - where Craig Fisher is being interviewed on a program.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He remembered the first time he’d seen Craig Fisher being interviewed on TV. ON BRAD - he stops listening to Troy and stares mesmerize the TV. He rises, pointing at Craig’s talking head.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The memory was like a cluster of needles in his heart. This wasn’t a fleeting jealousy. It was pain. It was real pain.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (calling toward kitchen) Melanie! CLOSER ON BRAD - as he digests this vision.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Why was it so painful? What was wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 5 10 INT. BRAD’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 10 Agitated and trying to get comfortable, Brad accidentally swats Melanie in the face, waking her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Brad!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Shit, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (half-asleep) What the hell? You just hit me in the face.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry. I can’t sleep. (beat) How much do you think your parents house is worth?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: My parents’ house? I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Like two million? Two and a half?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You've never thought about it?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (grabs his phone) It’‘ll say on Zillow.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (types into phone) It says 1.857. That seems low, no? For Seattle? 4300 square feet. Zillow is always low. I bet 2.5 at least. Don’t you think? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 6

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, aren’t you getting the house when they die?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: When they die? I mean, I split it with my brother.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: But your brother married into a ton of money. He and Vanessa don’t need your parents’ money.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter anyway, Brad. I mean...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Why? Because of climate change? You think the world’s gonna end before we retire?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Uh, no.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We might need that money, Mel.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I think they’re considering leaving it all to the grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Splitting everything among the grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What? Steve has three kids. And they’re already rich. We only have one. How’s that fair? 10 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 7

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: It’s not up to me. They’ve also thought about just leaving it all to charity so who knows?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Seriously? That’s absurd. That's mean.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You work for a non-profit - and you think that’s absurd?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Right. I work for a non-profit. And you work for the government. We need the money.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Look, I’m gonna be so distraught when my parents die, I’m not gonna give a fuck about the money.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Really? Not at all? I think you will.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What about your dad? You have money coming to you.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He’s an academic. Two hundred thousand dollars maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: It’‘ll help pay for Troy’s college. Is that why you’re worrying about money? We’ll be fine. We’1l figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Thank god we only had one kid.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: How much do you think your parents are worth total? Four? Five? Split in half. Then taxes. That’s like 1.5, 1.2. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 8

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRAD (cont'd) And they’1ll probably have health care shit to pay for - those senior living places can eat up the whole entire thing in no time...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I just feel like we’re running out of time here. There’s no more potential - this is it - we've plateaud - and clearly there’s not gonna be some windfall out of nowhere that’s gonna change the situation...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: We're not poor, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: In some circles. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What circles? The one per cent? Please. Go to sleep. Brad rolls over, then rolls back to her.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Stop thinking about this.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We didn’t work this hard to end up dying in a flophouse. You know?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (turning away from him) You're freaking me out. Enough. We have a great life.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I think you should talk to your parents and get some clarity. The grandkids don’t need the money. Especially Steve and Vanessa's. I've seen their posts. They live like Saudi Arabian princesses. They have their whole lives ahead of them anyway. You and I are done! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 13 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 9

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Please shut up. Brad shuts up. He stares into the middle distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is rising over Brad’s residential neighborhood - modest, but attractive homes. A YOUNG CYCLIST barrels down the center of the empty road SPRINKLERS go off at a nearby house. A NEIGHBOR closes his trash can and pulls it up the drive EXT. BRAD’S HOUSE - DAWN 11A ESTABLISHING SHOT as a CAR drives by. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - MORNING 12 A few images of the house. A FRAMED PHOTO of Brad, Melanie and their son, Troy - in photo, maybe nine years old. They are all smiling. A SUITCASE on ROLLERS is placed by the front door. INT. TROY’S BEDROOM - MORNING 13 Troy, now 17, sits in a towel on his bed, with his BULLDO Troy stares lovingly at the dog. CLOSE on Bulldog as he lifts his neck so Troy can scratch

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I know you get mad when I go away. Please don’t piss on the bed. Brad opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We have ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (rising) Yeah, I’m ready. I just gotta put on my clothes. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TROY (cont'd) (as BRAD lingers) Can you give me a second?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (surprised) Troy - you suddenly have the body of a man, man. 2016 - Page 9A 13 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 10

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Please don’t be weird, Dad. I’m stressed. 14 INT. MELANIE’S CAR - TRAVELING - DAY 14 Melanie drives, talking to Troy, who sits in the back. Br is in the passenger seat, looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I have it, Mom. It’s all on my phone.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Will you forward it to your dad? I don’t think he has any sense of the schedule. Do you Brad? (no response) I don’t think he has any idea. So it’s really on you, honey... CLOSE ON BRAD - he is lost in thought. We can HEAR Melani and Troy continue to talk in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The entire ride to the airport, Brad kept thinking about his protege, Chris Kanew - and about how Chris Kanew had quit that week. And all the things he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad sits at a LUNCH PLACE with a young colleague, CHRIS.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: So wait - I don’t understand? Sounds like you’re quitting.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (solemn nod) I am quitting. I got another job actually. I start in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What? Where?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: San Francisco. At City National. In their brokerage office. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 16 17 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 11

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You’re getting into banking?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (nods) I've loved working with you, Brad. I’ve learned a lot from you. But I think this job has made me... kinda depressed. And I actually think I can do more good by just making a lot of money - and giving it away. Instead of spending all my time asking other people for their money to give away. You know? Brad stares at him, floored. INT. MELANIE’S CAR - TRAVELING - DAY 16 As Melanie and Troy chat, Brad stares out the window, sin into a deep funk.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: As he remembered the exchange, Brad felt a hot flush of humiliation. He felt exposed in some essential and embarrassing way. It seemed so obvious that his life’s work was an absurdity. It might as well be tattooed across his face. Brad absently covers the invisible tattoo on his forehead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad pulls their bags from the trunk. Melanie comes gives Troy a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Call me all the time. I want to know everything. This is so exciting! I love you!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mom. Should be cool. Melanie approaches Brad. She’s emotional. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 19 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 12

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this. This is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He’s not leaving yet. We’re just looking at schools.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (in tears) I know. It just feels like a big moment. I’m so jealous. I wish I didn’t have this stupid conference. (composes herself; smiles) The flight info’s all on your phone - the hotels - it’s all there. Be happy. Be present. Okay? (hugs BRAD) And take pictures. I love you. Melanie gives Troy one last kiss, then gets back in the c They wave her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad hands his and Troy’s tickets to a TSA OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: TSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: The economy entrance is that line.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: TSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Business, first class only. Are you TSA Pre?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, but I have a Silver Flyer card.

dialogues.speaker: TSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sorry. Brad nods and shuffles off, with Troy in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy sit in the crowded terminal, waiting for th flight to board. Troy listens to music. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 20 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 13

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad watches - a YOUNG FATHER, nearby - playing with his TODDLER SON. After a moment, Brad turns to Troy and motions for him to take off his headphones. Troy does.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You know what I’m thinking? Let’s try for an upgrade.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: This is a big moment. You’re gonna go find your college. You and me - how many trips are we gonna have like this again? Let’s fly business.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Business. Really? Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I have a lot of miles I think. Might cost a little money. It’ll be fun. Let’s make this fucking special. Right?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’ve never flown business. Brad gives Troy an emphatic that-settles-it grin then ris

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad has waited his turn in line. He approaches the FEMAL AIRLINE REP.

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m flying today with my son - he’s a senior in high school and we're going East to look at colleges. (no response) Pretty cool. Umm, wondering if there’s any room in business so we could upgrade. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 14

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: Let me see. I believe there might be. Two of you are traveling? (taps away on computer) Good news. There are two seats available in business.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Awesome.

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: Can I see your tickets? Brad hands over his tickets. As she types...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I was hoping I could use my miles. I have a bunch of miles I think...

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, no - not for this flight, you can’t. The cost to upgrade to business would be eight hundred and twenty one dollars a ticket. (types away) So the total would be sixteen hundred and forty-two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Sixteen hundred dollars? For a domestic flight?

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: Sixteen forty-two, yes. (as he stalls) Do you want to go ahead and purchase the tickets?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Uh... hmmm... sixteen...

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: Do you want to sit down and think about it while I help some of the other passengers in line?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You know what, let’s just do it. (gets out wallet) I'll put it on the Amex. I mean, the MasterCard. No, the Amex. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 21 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 15

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: (takes card) Great! Let me just run that.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (justifying) It’s a once in a lifetime thing. My only kid - going to college.

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: Mr. Sloan, actually, unfortunately - we can’t upgrade you. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: It seems as though you bought your tickets on a discounted website. With that type of ticket, we can’t upgrade you.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Even if I pay sixteen hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: AIRLINE REP
dialogues.text: There’s actually no amount of money you could pay to get an upgrade. I’m so sorry. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Uh, no. It’s no big deal. What if I'm a Silver Flyer Member...? The Rep shakes her head and waves the next customer up. Brad, disappointed, returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad board the plane, passing... ...the PASSENGERS in FIRST CLASS. They are being served mimosas and champagne. They’re all wealthy and well-dress Brad looks at them as he slowly makes his way down the ai  22 23 24 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad sit toward the back of the plane. They look cramped and uncomfortable. Brad pulls out his SILVER FLYE CLUB MEMBER CARD from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I couldn’t get us the upgrade. I...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It’s no biggie.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: This Silver Flyer Card is totally meaningless. It means nothing. It gets you nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Well, get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m gonna. I’m tossing it. Should I? Yeah, fuck it - it’s trash. (nowhere to throw it) I'll just keep it for now. Brad puts it back in his wallet and SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy listens to music and thumbs through a magazine. Brad deep in thought, looks out the plane’s window.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On the flight, Brad wondered when was the last time Craig Fisher flew economy. Probably not in decades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE Craig Fisher, sitting in First Class, drinking a mimosa, approached by a FLIGHT ATTENDANT.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad imagined Craig enjoying all the perks of first class.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Mr. Fisher, can I offer you a warm towel? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 26 27 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 17

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Warm towel. Yes, thank you. With a tong, she hands him a towel. Craig places it over his face and reclines in his cushy s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason Hatfield and his ELEGANT WIFE and their FOUR TOWHEA CHILDREN cross a tarmac towards their PRIVATE PLANE.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Then Brad thought about how Jason Hatfield has his own private plane. Probably never has to fly commercial at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick Pascale and his BOYFRIEND and their DOGS get out of HELICOPTER and cross the tarmac, then walk the stairs to their private plane.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Nick Pascale probably flies private, too. Brad thought what a high it must be for these guys to always feel important and special and better than. It must be like a drug - a drug Brad distrusted yet coveted, and never seemed to have the opportunity to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hatfield family enters the plane. They begin eating, playing, taking pictures.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad imagined all the great vacations they went on - the exotic destinations. Jason and his wife drink champagne from flutes, then chuc the glasses. She then takes a selfie of her and Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same SELFIE PHOTO is on an INSTAGRAM page of JACQUELI HATFIELD. WE SEE Brad scrolling through Jason’s wife’s Instagram pa a sour look on his face. ON PHONE - more PHOTOS of Jason’s family living the good life.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The adventures. And the sense of possibility. No door ever closed. Everything an option. Brad puts away the phone and stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The world for them is not a battlefield. Not even an obstacle course. He looks out at the clouds and the landscape below.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It’s a playground. A dream. A Heaven manifest. Troy taps Brad on the shoulder. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT stands behind him with her cart.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad, can I get some Pringles? They’re seven dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Seven dollars? Yeah. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I need your credit card. Brad pulls out his wallet and hands over the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy has fallen asleep. Brad sits and stares, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad's thoughts soon drifted back to his college days at Tufts.  30

dialogues.speaker: 30A
dialogues.text: 31 32 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The late ‘80’s. From a grassy knoll, we WATCH a GROUP of MALE STUDENTS gather and greet each other. It’s a nostalg beautiful image.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Wasn’t Brad then the golden boy? Wasn’t he the one destined for great things? How did he end up the one compromised by life and living in the margins? Brad likened it in his mind to a love affair. When he was young, he was in love with the world. And the world loved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCREECH of TIRES on the runway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane has just landed. It taxis across the runway.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It pained him to admit the world had fallen out of love with him first. This realization made him want to cry. Brad looks like he might cry, then realizes Troy is talki to him.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: ...-they say air travel leaves a huge carbon footprint - and with so many people flying now, it’s a big contributor to global warming. Kinda sucks. Brad snaps out of it, feigns attention to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Welcome to Boston. Local time here is 6:15 PM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICONIC BOSTON SPOTS from inside a moving TAXI.  BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 19A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy are in the back of a taxi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 33A
dialogues.text: 34 35 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 20

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In the cab ride to the hotel, Brad tried to locate the moment where things had gone wrong for him. And when. His first thought was Melanie. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 33A Brad works at the dining room table. He looks over at Melanie - she has pulled Troy close to her and plays with hair as they watch TV. The Bulldog is in Troy’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Yes, Melanie was a great mother and she loved Brad and was clearly happy with their life together. Melanie looks over at him and smiles. He smiles back. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT 34 Brad and Melanie are having a discussion in the kitchen a they make dinner. Brad approaches her with a spoonful of sauce to try.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But she was also easily satisfied - and maybe her contentment undermined his ambition. Melanie tastes the pasta and smiles, nodding. Brad remain skeptical that it tastes good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick Pascale’s Boyfriend shows him a watch in a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Nick Pascale’s boyfriend obviously loved expensive things. Maybe his appetites spurred Nick’s drive to succeed. Nick takes out a WATCH BOX and hands it to Xavier. Xavier opens it - it’s the same watch. Xavier exults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 20A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason Hatfield’s elegant Wife smooths down one of her daughter’s pinafores and arranges her hair.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And Jason Hatfield’s wife was a blue blood. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 38 39 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 21

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) She had introduced him to rich clients, given him entree and status, and showed him the ways of the American aristocracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and his wife, DIANE, are both being interviewed separately on a red carpet before an event.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And Diane Fisher was a celebrated intellectual herself. She and Craig competed with each other - and that dynamic had driven Craig to become a stand-out in his field. They stop and pose for photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad's PHONE - he is now looking at PHOTOS of Craig and D at the same event on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Maybe Brad had married the wrong woman. Brad reacts to the photos. BACK ON PHONE - an incoming call - the screen reads “MELANIE”. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, honey. Yep, we made it - we're on our way to the hotel. How’s it going there? Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad hands over his credit card to the EMPLOYEE at the REGISTRATION DESK. Troy lingers nearby. As the Employee runs Brad’s card... ..-Brad eye-balls an OLDER MAN beside him, complaining to another HOTEL EMPLOYEE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 40 4l BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 22

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: There’s this draft, moving the curtains - and I’m hearing this constant whistle and it’s driving me crazy... + eH

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad's suspicions then turned to his father. INT. BRAD’S PARENTS’ HOUSE - NIGHT 40 BRAD'S DAD, a rumpled academic, sits in a reading chair, jotting his thoughts onto a yellow legal pad.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His dad had been a professor and had spent years writing an exhaustive study on Institutional Fascism that was never published. Brad's Dad reads over what he’s just written, finds it lacking and scratches it out. He starts over.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad found his father self-pitying and defensive. INT. BRAD’S PARENTS’ KITCHEN - NIGHT 41 * Brad and his dad, now older, have an argument over dinner

dialogues.speaker: BRAD'S DAD
dialogues.text: I don’t need the humiliation. I know they have no interest. It’s not about vampire children - or whatever. These publishing houses... As his dad pontificates, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His lifelong commitment to exposing the tyranny of the powerful had hardened over the years into a crippling paranoia. It bothered Brad that his father had no perspective on his own failings - but found fault everywhere else. The Sociology department, the University, corporate America. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 23

dialogues.speaker: BRAD'S DAD
dialogues.text: The values of society have become the values of the ruling class. Forget about subversion. Brad, exasperated, shakes his head and gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason Hatfield’s FATHER and MOTHER have joined the family They are a distinguished-looking older couple. Jason and Father have an animated conversation, while his Mother attends to her grandkids. We SEE the plane in the b.g. *

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Jason Hatfield’s dad had been a state senator and a businessman. Steadfast, uncomplicated, cheerful. Of course Jason had been given all the tools he needed to succeed. They all stand to exit. A hand reaches in for a forgotten sweater. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Troy unpacks his bag, Brad sits on the bed, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Unlike Brad, who had inherited his father’s indecisiveness, his authority complexes, his tendency to lay blame. Even now, here he was blaming his father for his own disappointments. Brad shakes his head with self-loathing.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Enough. Brad's choices were his. Brad did it. He’s the piece of shit. Suddenly, Troy tosses his baseball cap, hitting Brad’s he

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad. Brad looks up, a bit stupefied. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26,

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You deaf? I was asking you if you wanted to go get some food. 2016 - Page 23A 43 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 24

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (rallying) Yeah. Let’s do it. Let’s get some food. I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: All I’ve eaten today is that can of Pringles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad sit, looking at menus. Everyone else in the restaurant is old and Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: This menu is pretty weird.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Not sure where else to go.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I thought you went to school here.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Tufts is another part of town. And it was twenty-five years ago. (forces a grin) This is cool, hunh? We're really doing it! You want to go over your schedule?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Not really, but okay. (off BRAD’s look) It’s on your phone. I sent it to you. Brad takes out his phone and looks up the e-mail.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (reading) Okay, tomorrow Harvard - interview and tour.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: And then I’m supposed to meet up with this girl from high school who goes there. She’s in the music department so... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 25

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Wednesday - Tufts interview and tour. That’s gonna be weird - I haven't been back there in so long. (shrugs) Okay, then Thursday - we rent the car - drive to Amherst - then Williams... (looks up) These are all competitive schools, Troy. You have some safety schools you're applying to?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Just try not to get too caught up in the game. The brands. Don’t put too much pressure on yourself. It all works out. In the end, you end up at the right place.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’m not worried.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’m just stoked to get out of Sac. Everything else is gravy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Ahh, Sacramento’s all right. Troy lets out a little laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You'll miss your parents.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: That’s true.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: When I was your age, I was so freaked out about college. I wanted to go to Yale. I was obsessed. I don’t even know why. Why Yale? Then I got wait-listed - and then I didn’t get in. But it all worked out. I loved Tufts. Tufts was a fantastic school. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 26

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRAD (cont'd) Made great friends. I hada professor - Bob Connor - took me under his wing - blew my mind - changed my life - made me want to save the world. Brad's mind drifts for a bit, then he returns.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Anyway, fuck Yale. You know what I’m saying? And if you don’t get into Tufts, fuck Tufts.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: My counselor thinks I’1l get into Yale. It takes Brad a moment to process this.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: She does?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He does? (off TROY’s nod) Why does he think that?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. My grades. My scores. My compositions - I guess a lot of these schools want to fill orchestral spots. (shrugs) My counselor's pretty confident I‘’1l get in everywhere I apply. (off BRAD’s look; laughs) What? You look stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No. I just... do you think this guy knows what he’s talking about?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: He’s been doing it for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He thinks you’ll get into Yale? (off TROY’s nod) That’s amazing. Really? Wow. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 27 44

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRAD (cont'd) I mean, I knew you had good grades. I’ve always thought you were a genius. But I just... That is so awesome, Troy. (beams, then...) But we’re not visiting Yale.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go to Yale.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I'm hoping I‘’1l get into Harvard. There’s a music professor there - this guy, Jerome Backaly. And he’s doing really cool stuff. And I don’t know - it’s a cool program. I just have this feeling...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You should meet him while you're here!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I'd like to. My friend from school - she says, there’s a concert Wednesday night she’s playing - and he might be there. So...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (amazed) You're going to Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Well, maybe - I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Does your mother know this?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: She knows I want to.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I just can’t believe I didn’t know this.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You knew we were coming here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 28

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I knew we were checking out the school - but I didn’t know you were actually gonna get in.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I might not get in.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: But it sounds like you might?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah, I might.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (elated) My kid’s going to Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t fucking jinx me, dude. Brad is soon full of emotion. He works to keep it in chec

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You okay, Dad? Brad nods, composing himself.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Life’s crazy. How cool. Proud of you. Brad looks like he might cry. The WAITRESS arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (looks up) Hi. We’re here visiting colleges. My son’s first choice is Harvard. Troy rolls his eyes, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Okay. And what would he like to eat?  45 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy lie back on their twin beds, both illuminat by the glow of their laptops. On Brad - he is wide-eyed, energized - as he stares at th computer screen. We can HEAR classical piano leaking from his ear buds.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad was electrified by this latest development. Here - suddenly - an unexpected lifeline - something tangible - an outward proof. ON COMPUTER - Brad is watching a home video of Troy playi piano. He’s clearly a prodigy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Of course. His child. His son. Brad has tears in his eyes as he watches the video.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: A genius. With substance. His heart could burst with this deep satisfaction. He looks over at... ...Troy, watching GAME OF THRONES on his laptop.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad realized along the way, he’d somehow lost the plot. Cured of his amnesia, he now remembered what he’d been doing for the last seventeen years. Troy senses he’s being watched. He looks over. Brad gives Troy a big, prideful grin.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Planting and nurturing and modeling for this miraculous creature. Troy smiles back, bemused, then turns back to the show. Brad looks out into the middle distance, contemplative. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 47 48 49 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 30

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It occurred to Brad that Billy Werstler and Nick Pascale didn’t even have kids. EXT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 46 Nick and his Husband have a pool party at their LA mansio with a bunch of YOUNG, ATHLETIC GUYS.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The pleasures in their lives were like candy, Brad thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy makes out with an attractive GIRL in the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Sugary, addictive, but ultimately empty, even potentially harmful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad puts away the laptop, smiling to himself.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Not like the profound and sustaining pleasure Brad was experiencing right now. Troy is now crouching in front of the mini-bar cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad, can I have this Toblerone?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Of course. As Troy opens the Toblerone...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In this new light, Brad reconsidered all his regrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s mayhem in the Hatfield family’s private plane. The k are all acting bratty, complaining and arguing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 51 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 31

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jason Hatfield looks irritated, ignoring the chaos as he tries to work on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: If he had pursued money and power like Jason Hatfield, Troy might have ended up spoiled and entitled. One of the young boys snorts a line of COCAINE off a tray

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Maybe on hard drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Diane Fisher and their TWEEN TWIN GIRLS, in the Brooklyn hipster fashion, have a discussion over brunch.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And if he had married a striver like Diane Fisher and stayed in New York, his kids could have been self- important and unbearable.

dialogues.speaker: TWEEN TWIN ONE
dialogues.text: We need capital for our digital newsletter. You must know investors.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, what is it exactly?

dialogues.speaker: TWEEN TWIN TWO
dialogues.text: We've told you, Dad. Feminist theory and shopping tips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy hands Brad the last chunk of Toblerone. Brad pops it his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (to himself; chewing) Thank God for Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hunh? Brad suddenly tickles Troy. They rough house a bit before Troy pushes Brad away.  52

dialogues.speaker: 52B
dialogues.text: 53 54 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad sleep soundly in their beds. They both SNOR

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: For the first time in months, Brad slept through the night without waking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad walk the bridge from Boston to Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad enter the Harvard gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad walk to the ADMISSIONS BUILDING.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You nervous?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Not really. I guess, a little.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I know you. You’ve got this.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad. Brad opens the door to the ADMISSIONS OFFICE and they ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad looks at some photos on the wall: An old photo of YOUNG, WHITE HARVARD STUDENTS from the 1800's. Another old photo of YOUNG, WHITE HARVARD STUDENTS from t 1950's A third photo of YOUNG, ETHNICALLY DIVERSE STUDENTS from present day. Brad crosses and sits, next to another waiting MOTHER. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 33

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You have a son? Daughter?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yes, a son - he’s interviewing.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Mine, too. Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: St. Petersburg.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Russia??

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Florida.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Okay. My son is a very talented musician. Pianist. Keyboard. And he composes his own music so...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Looks like he’s gonna have a lot of decisions to make. I think Harvard - is definitely in the running though.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (dry) You think Harvard has a chance?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What does your son, uh, do?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: What does he do? He’s a student in high school.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Right, right. (sizes her up) Okay. Suddenly, a sheepish Troy appears. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13,

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (confused) What happened? Is it over?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I got the day wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I got the day wrong. It’s yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yesterday. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don’t know, I fucked it up. It was yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Did they give you a time to come back?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I think they’re pretty booked up. They said I could do an alumni interview back in Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Noooo. You don’t want to do that. You want to do it with one of these guys. These are the guys that decide. (to the MOTHER) Right? The Mother shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna go on the tour. It’s not a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It IS a big deal. Let me talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: No, Dad, no. 2016 - Page 34 54 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 An ADMISSIONS OFFICER talks to Brad. BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 35 54

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m going to. We didn’t come all this way so you could have an interview in Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: ADMISSIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: I'd love to be able to accommodate you guys - but our schedule’s been set - for months.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We flew from Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: ADMISSIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: We have a pretty small staff here...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I just want you to get a sense of my son. Harvard is his first choice. So...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad - it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He’s a pianist. He does community service. His counselor says he’s Harvard material.

dialogues.speaker: ADMISSIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: It’s not necessary to have an interview here. Alumni interviews are just as good.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. I know how important face time is, okay? We’re here. Come on. Don’t shine us.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Can’t you just sit with him for ten minutes? What are you doing right now? 55 Troy hovers, anxious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 56 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 -

dialogues.speaker: ADMISSIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: I have a staff meeting.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (grabs Brad’s arm) Please, please, please. Please. Brad registers Troy’s plaintive look and relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad have exited. They argue on the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What the fuck, Dad? You think arguing with the admissions officer is gonna help my chances?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He won’t remember this.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I think he will.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I don’t understand - how can someone who has the brain to get into Harvard, not have the brain to remember what day he made an appointment - so he could get into Harvard?!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me to fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Can we walk somewhere else please? They’re about to start a tour.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t want everyone seeing me get bitched out by my dad, okay? Page 36 55 56 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 37 P g 56

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m not bitching you out. I’m trying to solve a problem here. You need to have an interview. I mean, we’re here. That’s the point.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I thought the point was for me to get a sense of the school.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, the point is for the school to get a sense of you. You need to make an impression. I know you think you have this in the bag. But it’s Harvard. Even geniuses get rejected, Troy. Troy looks over and sees - a group of APPLICANTS and thei PARENTS gathering for a tour.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You realize we’re competing with kids from Hong Kong and everywhere! Okay? You're a white kid from the suburbs without a sob story. And you’re not even a legacy. We're underdogs here - we need to do everything we can.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Dad - I’m about to flip the fuck out. Please shut up.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Let me think. Go on the tour - and I will meet you back here when it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m gonna make some calls. Troy looks uneasy - but the tour is leaving. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 38

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Just don’t do anything uncool. Brad grimaces and takes out his phone. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - MORNING 57 Melanie is feeding the BULLDOG, on her CELL PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Troy messed up - we’re here at Harvard and he doesn’t have an interview. He got the day wrong. Do we know anyone at Harvard? I want to get him an interview. They need to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Who's at Harvard? Like a... like a... like a... dean?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (excited) Babe, Harvard is Troy's first choice. Did you know that? And his counselor thinks he can get in? Did you know that? Who do we know at Harvard?!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I mean... I gotta think. Toni Morrison?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Toni Morrison? You know Toni Morrison?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: She teaches at Princeton, Melanie. What the fuck are you talking about, Toni Morrison? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13,

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Who would I know at Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You know people in government. Someone musta gone to Harvard. Think. It’s Troy’s future.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I met one of the Kennedys in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She's a yoga instructor. Doesn't Craig Fisher teach a class there?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What? No. Does he?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I think I read that somewhere. I think he’s a visiting lecturer or something. He flies up from D.C.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He lives in New York now.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: He flies up from New York then. I’m pretty sure he lectures there, teaches a class or...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Fuuuuuck!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I think you’re right. Now that you mention it... shit!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I don’t want to call him. Ugh. Goddammit. 2016 - Page 39 57 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 57C
dialogues.text: 58 59 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 40 57

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: What’s the big deal?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (sighs; full of dread) I’1l call you later. Melanie realizes he’s hung up. EXT. Brad EXT. Brad EXT. Brad EXT. Brad INT. Brad Brad

dialogues.speaker: HARVARD UNIVERSITY
dialogues.text: exits the campus, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: walks through Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: crosses toward the Charles River.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RIVER
dialogues.text: sits on a bench, watching STUDENT ROWERS in BOATS pass.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad thought about the last time he’d seen Craig Fisher.

dialogues.speaker: MANHATTAN DINER
dialogues.text: and Craig have lunch in a crowded diner.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: They had both been in New York City for different reasons - and decided to meet up. Brad had just started his non-profit - and was full of enthusiasm. animatedly pitches Craig.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He had hoped Craig might want to get involved in some way. Offer up his famous friends. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 61 62 63 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 41

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) Even donate money. But Craig never took the bait. Craig listens politely - takes a bite of his sandwich. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - OFFICE - DAY 60 Brad sits at his computer and feverishly types an e-mail.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Later, back in Sacramento, he decided to be more direct. He sent Craig an e-mail, asking him to come onto Brad’s board of directors. He wrote passionately about the worthiness of the cause, his deep respect for Craig and how much it would mean to him, personally. Brad reads over his e-mail, pleased. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - DINING ROOM - NIGHT 61 Brad, Melanie and a Young Troy (six) eat dinner. Brad checks his Blackberry - nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad never heard back. INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 62 Brad, sitting alone, watches... ...Craig being interviewed - on a CABLE NEWS SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In fact, he never heard from Craig again. Brad grimaces and changes the channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on the bench, Brad stares at his phone, consideri what to do.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Fuck it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 64 65 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 42

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He places the call to Craig. He HEARS...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Welcome to Verizon wireless. Your call cannot be completed as dialed. Please check the number and try again. Brad hangs up, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT in a handsomely-appointed office s answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Jason Hatfield's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad rises and paces near the river.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hi. Brad Sloan calling for him.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Jason's not available right now. Can I take a message?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It’s kind of time-sensitive. Can you just tell him Brad Sloan is calling?

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: I would, but he’s on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh. I see. I’m trying to get a phone number - I’m an old friend of his from college - and I’m looking for a phone number of another friend of ours...?

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Does Jason have your number?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I think so, but maybe... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 67 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 43

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: I‘11 let him know you called.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Okay, but, maybe could... hello? He realizes she’s hung up. Annoyed, Brad wracks his brain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Werstler walks the beach with his DOG. He answers h PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Brad?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad paces along the pedestrian footbridge.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yo! What's up?! Billy! How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Dude! I’m good! It’s like six AM here.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Ah, shit. Did I call too early?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nah, man - I’m already on the beach - taking my dog for a piss.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Great, cool, well, how’s life?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Life's fucking good, dude! It’s excellent!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You're like retired. Amazing!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: In Maui! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You're like living the dream!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Pretty much! Although I’m not really retired. I put some money into this beach bar here - and then it just blew up. Now, it’s getting franchised all over Hawaii. And it’s even coming to the mainland. So that’s keeping me busy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Wow, great.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: And I’m also involved in this Polynesian cultural society which is really cool - trying to get the islanders more involved in local politics...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Good for you, man.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: And I've got these two beautiful wahine who live with me. And they're fucking gorgeous and cool. They make these amazing necklaces made from shells and shit - I’m helping them open a store. (laughs) We surf and fuck then surf - it’s awesome.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Wait - so you have two girlfriends - that live with you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It's pretty fluid. We’re making it up as we go along. You know. Anyway, what's up with you?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m in Boston right now with my son, Troy - we're looking at colleges. Yeah. He’s probably gonna go to Harvard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13,

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Sweet.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah. He’s a smart kid. The real deal. Anyway, hey, do you happen to have Craig’s number? I wanted to ask him something and I guess he changed it...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can text it to you. I just saw him in LA at Nick’s wedding.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Wait - Nick got married? To who?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: To Xavier.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I thought they were married.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No, they just lived together. They finally got married in July.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I thought I’d see you there for sure. Craig was there. Jason and all his Aryan spawn were there. It was actually cool. Beautiful ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah? I didn’t know about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It was real small. Somebody mentioned you. I forget who.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (stung) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wondering where you were. Or what happened to you. Who was it? 2016 - Page 45 67 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 68 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 46

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh. Hunh. Well, I’m just doing my thing.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Dude, it’s good to hear your voice. My dog just took a shit though and I gotta pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Okay. Good to talk to you, Billy. Text me that number, would ya?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yup. I/’11 send it right now. Come to the islands sometime, brother. Later!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Bye. Brand hangs up. He looks gut-punched. He sits for a moment, stewing. His PHONE BUZZES. He looks down - it’s a text from BILLY with Craig’s Brad stares at the number and frowns. He presses the number, calling. The PHONE RINGS once, then goes to VOICE MAIL.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE
dialogues.text: Please leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (into PHONE; stammers) Hey, Craig - it’s, uh, Brad Sloan. Ummmm... I’m at Harvard with my son. He’s ummm... if you could - if you have the time, uhhh, could you call me back? It’s kind of on the urgent side. Thanks. Brad hangs up and SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad wanders across from the campus, in a funk. number. 68 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 70 71 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 47

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad felt numb. The fact that he’d not been invited to Nick Pascale’s wedding seemed to confirm every doubt he ever had - about his friendships, himself and his place in the world. Brad stops in his tracks. INT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 69 A small wedding party. Nick and Xavier are congratulated Craig and Diane, then Jason Hatfield and his family.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad kept picturing the wedding party in his mind. Everyone there, enjoying themselves. Basking in each other’s glow. EXT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 70 We watch Nick and Xavier exit the house and greet people the expansive lawn. They are approached by Billy and his tan Girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad wondered if he’d been excluded or simply forgotten and couldn’t decide which was worse. Everyone continues hugging each other and enjoying the da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad shakes his head, grimacing.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Whatever. He was a non-presence. A blip. A zero. A no-name. For a moment, he wished he were dead. TWO HARVARD GIRLS pass by him, laughing about something. This snaps him out of it. He watches them pass, then looks over... ..-under a tree, there is a HOMELESS WOMAN, talking to herself. She looks miserable. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 72 73 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 48

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad takes her in - his compassion visible on his face.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad felt a sudden kinship with everything that was ever unloved. CLOSE on Brad as he spots about other sad creatures. - A MISERABLE TEEN GIRL, looking lonely, passes; An ASIAN LADY, struggling with a heavy grocery bag; An OLD MAN, al on a bench, feeding pigeons. He then looks at the HEADSTONES of an old GRAVEYARD.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The abandoned, the forgotten, the despised - those who never found love. Never, ever, ever. INT. BRAD’S PARENTS’ HOUSE - OFFICE - DAY 72 Brad's Dad, looking old and frail, searches for something his den.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad thought about his father and how his book had been rejected by every single publisher. How lonely he was. How little affirmation he received - even from Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad is now emotional as he wanders back toward the campu

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: How cruel is this world. How unfair. The prejudices of humans who shower their attention on the already popular - and ignore those who need it the most. Brad wipes his tears, just as... .+.a chipper Troy appears.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad. (sees his face) What’s wrong? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 74 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 49

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (composing himself) Nothing. What happened to the tour?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It’s over.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’ve been gone an hour and a half.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Really? Oh.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Wanna get something to eat? Brad nods and they head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy walk a busy street.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What about here? Brad points to a MEXICAN RESTAURANT that is completely em save for an OLDER WOMAN, working the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: There’s no one in there, Dad. What about that place? Troy points across the street, where there’s a FESTIVE LU PLACE and a CROWD is dining, al fresco.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Just because no one’s in here doesn’t mean it’s not good, Troy.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Usually it does, actually.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, it doesn’t. Why don’t we go somewhere that really needs our business instead of some trendy popular place where we’d have to wait to get a table? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 75 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 50 74

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t really feel like Mexican, but okay. Troy follows Brad inside the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 TWO PLATES OF UNAPPETIZING FOOD are set down on the table Troy frowns at the sight. Brad looks up at the OLD LATINA and smiles brightly.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Muchisimas gracias!

dialogues.speaker: OLD LATINA
dialogues.text: (lackluster) De nada. The Old Latina walks off.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: So I may have a connection at Harvard - and I made a call. But I don’t want you to get your hopes up.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It’s not that big a deal.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I just wish I could help you here. Brad shakes his head, glum.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I have interviews everywhere else. And I can do an alumni interview for Harvard. It’s fine. (looks at BRAD) Something wrong, Dad? You seem a little off.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, it’s just... nothing... it’s stupid...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 76 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 51

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Ah, just some... I don’t know... some old friends got together and... (struggles; softly) ...didn’t invite me... ‘cause I’m not, you know, at their, whatever... they’re... it’s just random...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What? You’re kinda mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I wouldn’t have even wanted to go if I'd been invited, but - it’s just kinda, I dunno... lame. Troy gives his dad a consoling look.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Brad shrugs it off, forcing a grin.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: They sound like dicks. Brad lets out a wry laugh, brightening. Suddenly, Brad’s PHONE BUZZES. He takes it out and answer

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hello? Heeey, Craig! Brad gives Troy a hopeful look, pointing to phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: How’s it going, man?! What? No, nobody died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig stands in the wings of a NEWS STUDIO SET. We can SE CAMERA CREW and NEWS ANCHORS in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You sounded weird on the message and you said it was urgent so I...

dialogues.speaker: PHONE CALL
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 52

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, no. Sorry, didn’t mean to... I’m just up here in Cambridge with my son, looking at Harvard - and he was supposed to get an interview at the admissions office. And someone messed up over there. Yeah! Brad notices Troy scrutinizing his every word.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hold on a sec - I’m in a restaurant - just gonna step out. Brad rises and exits. Troy watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad paces on the street.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I knew you taught a class up here or something. I thought maybe you could help me out...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Sure, Brad. No problem. I can call over there after I finish this taping.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Really? That would be so amazing. Thank you! Harvard is Troy's first choice - I mean, obviously...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You know, I’m actually flying up there tomorrow. You guys still gonna be around?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? Yeah, we’re here. We leave Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Maybe we can grab a bite to eat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 52A

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: That’‘d be great! Cool, listen, one last thing - Troy’s a musician - like a true prodigy - I’m not saying that just ‘cause he’s my kid. Anyway, there’s a professor here he’d really love to meet with. Oh, shit.  78 79 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad runs into the restaurant, frantic.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (cupping phone) What’s the name of that music professor?!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: The music professor! The one you like! C’mon, c'mon!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Jerome Backaly?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (into phone) Jerome Backaly. Yeah. That would be terrific, Craig. Man, I owe you. Fantastic! Yeah, dinner tomorrow. Yep! Talk soon! Hey - have a good, uh, taping! Brad hangs up, feeling a mixture of emotions.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m on it, okay? I’m on it. Brad gives Troy a confident, cryptic look. Troy rolls his eyes and returns to his burrito.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy strolls the aisles, looking at various books on musi Nearby, Brad pulls a book off a display table. ON BOOK - “POLITICAL BEASTS by CRAIG FISHER”. Brad reads a little of the book - contempt all over his f He turns over the book... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 54

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On the back - a PHOTO of Craig, arms folded, with a take- seriously expression. Brad sticks out his tongue, nauseated. Suddenly, Brad’s PHONE BUZZES. He takes it from his pocke

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (into phone) Craig! Hey! Guess what? I’m ina book store right now, looking at your book! The new one, yeah. It’s got a big display here! (eyes widen) Yeah?! Seriously? Man, you are the best! I don’t even know how to thank you! But in his excitement, Brad drops the book onto the table

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I can’t wait to tell Troy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An excited Brad approaches Troy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Guess who you got a meeting with tomorrow morning!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Jerome Backaly.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: And after - you’ve got an interview - with the Dean of Admissions himself!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: No way! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 81 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 55 80

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Way!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Now, I’m nervous!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Shit! Wait, but tomorrow I have Tufts.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Fuck Tufts!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Right, right.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We'll go in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You're the King!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (grins) I got you, pal. They high-five, both in great spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad approaches Troy with a Harvard sweatshirt.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Coming through for his son made Brad giddy. What if these meetings really did help Troy get into Harvard? Troy shakes his head, but then takes the sweatshirt with sheepish smile. 81  82 83 84 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 56 INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - DAY 82 A euphoric Troy races into the room.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I got in! I got in! At the table, Brad and Melanie leap to their feet, exulti

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And what if, looking back, this was the fateful moment that started Troy onto a path of unimaginable glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie and Brad pull a WIRED MAGAZINE off the shelf. The cover is a picture of TROY with the headline - “WUNDERKIND STARTS A MUSICAL REVOLUTION”.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He pictured Troy as an adult, happy and wealthy, even famous. Brad and Melanie hold each other as they stare at the cov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy, well-dressed and confident, sits across from Melani and Brad. Troy has a beautiful GIRLFRIEND by his side.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad, Mom, I love you so much. All my success is because of you. Melanie and Brad react, touched.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Guess what? I bought an island! As Troy starts to show them photos on his phone, we HEAR.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He pictured Troy’s triumphs eclipsing those of Brad’s contemporaries. How gratifying that would be.  85 86 87 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy have exited the store with their purchases. Troy tries on the sweatshirt for his dad. Brad's expression seems to change as Troy models his new Harvard sweatshirt.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Brad was struck with a pang of anxiety. Troy takes the sweatshirt off again - embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: What if Troy lorded his success over Brad - or hoarded it away? INT. BRAD’S HOUSE - NIGHT 86 Brad and Melanie watch... ON TV - Troy is being interviewed by JIMMY KIMMEL.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: What if, in the end, Troy’s wins made Brad feel even more the loser? In his chair, Brad is feeling a mixture of emotions.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Did he call you back yet? Brad shakes his head. Melanie frowns.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: What if they became estranged, alienated by their diverging fortunes? INT. BRAD’S OFFICE - DAY 87 A stung Brad takes down the framed WIRED MAGAZINE COVER o Troy from the wall above his desk.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: What if Brad ended up envious of his own son? Brad drops the FRAMED PORTRAIT into a storage box.  88 89 90 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy walk across a busy intersection. Brad’s expression has turned grim.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The thought horrified him. At the corner, they pass a YOUNG BUSKER, singing and strumming his GUITAR. Brad pauses for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But, then again, musicians don’t really make money. Brad looks over at Troy - who has also stopped to listen, enjoying the music.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Maybe even with an expensive education, Brad could wind up a struggling artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, it is Troy busking on a Cambridge street, playing mu on his keyboard for the PASSERS-BY.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Maybe Troy will take after Melanie - perfectly satisfied with practically nothing. A PEDESTRIAN drops a dollar into Troy’s upturned hat. Tro smiles, appreciative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy, looking like a white-trash thug, and a few DIRTBAG FRIENDS smoke a joint and drink beers on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Or worse, end up like Brad - bitter and restless and full of regrets. Maybe even blaming Brad for all of life’s disappointments. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
