dialogues.text: 90 91 92 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 59

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (to another GUY) My dad’s a fucking loser, too... Troy takes a swig, then tosses his beer can into the stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy listen to the Busker finish his song. The song ends. Brad and Troy and a few others CLAP. Troy drops a FIVE into the Busker’s hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy change clothes for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: If you’re just gonna be a musician, do you even need to go to college?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hunh?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It's a fair question.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Just a musician?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m just saying - do you need a Harvard diploma to play music ina band? Isn’t that what you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I want to do, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, you need to start thinking about it - ‘cause this isn’t cheap, Troy. You're assuming a lot if you think I can pay for all this without taking out loans - and you taking out loans - and trying to get scholarships - and financial aid... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 93 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 60

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What the fuck just happened?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (softens) I’m just thinking out loud, okay?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t expect you to pay for everything. (beat) Are you not gonna be able to pay for everything?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We'll see. Look, I don’t want you to worry about that - yet.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hey, it might not be a big issue. Maybe one of your grandparents will die. Troy reacts, disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brad and Troy step off the elevator, they see... .+.a beautiful young Indian-American woman, ANANYA, (21) standing in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Hey, Troy. She approaches and they hug.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: This is my dad, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Hey, dad Brad. I’m Ananya. Ananya and Brad shake hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 61

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: So you guys were friends at Country Day?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Not really. Well, Ananya was a Senior and I was a Freshman...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: (protesting) We were friends.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You were nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: We were in orchestra together.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Ananya’s an amazing musician.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: And now you go to Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: (nods) I’m a Junior.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Are you liking it?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Iam. It gets cold, but yeah, I love my classes. Great people. Yeah, no complaints!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Is it a lot of work? (off her emphatic nod) Listen, if you have a lot of work to do, you don’t have to go to dinner with us. Please...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I turned in a paper this afternoon. I’m done for the night. And I’m glad to see faces from home! I got a reservation at a place around the corner. Should we go? Ananya leads them toward the door.  BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy sit across from Ananya.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: That’s cool you got a meeting with Jerome Backaly. How’d you manage that?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: My dad's friends with a professor here.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Who?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: His name’s Craig Fisher. Ananya grimaces, then recovers.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You made a face.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You definitely made a face. You can say whatever you want. We’re not close or anything. We were friends a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Well, I just took his class last year - he’s kind of the worst. (smiles; self-conscious) Should I have not said that?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No. Say it. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: He’s just condescending. And I don’t know - he’s pretty sexist. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 63 94

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANANYA (cont'd) He’s just got this air of someone who thinks they know everything because they’re on TV and... they have contacts at the White House.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: So how do you really feel?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: The way he sees politics - it’s all a game. Who’s up. Who’s down. It’s doesn’t inspire me. Honestly - by the end of his class, I wanted to quit my major.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Aren’t you a music major?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Government. I love music, but I want to get into public policy.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: My dad majored in Government.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Communications and Government. This was at Tufts. Actually, Craig and I were in all the same classes.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Really? Was he like... a cocky prick then, too?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (smiles) Not as bad, I don’t think.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: So what do you do now?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I have a non-profit I started a few years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Really? Awesome. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 64 94

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We help other non-profits use social media to get the word out about what they do - help them find members and donors and...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Like crowd sourcing or...?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Some of that. We’re consultants, basically. It sounds boring...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t sound boring. It sounds amazing.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (pleased) Well, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: I'm actually writing my thesis on NGO’s - maybe I could talk to you at some point...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Of course. Whatever you need.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Thanks. I once told my dad my dream job was to work at Amnesty International - he was like devastated. He wanted to disown me. (to TROY) You’re lucky your dad’s so cool.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (nods) I am lucky.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Tell us about your thesis...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Really? It’s not fully formed but I want to write about the history of white missionary women - you know, the wives? - and how they came to India and Sri Lanka to “convert the heathens” but laid the ground work for social reform... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 65

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Ananya talks, Brad soaks her up. Ananya’s voice fades we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: As she spoke, Brad became increasingly smitten. Ananya seemed to embody all the qualities he still loved about humanity. Here was someone who was young, but wise. Engaged, aware - but still idealistic. She almost gave Brad hope for the future of the species.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Their food has come. Ananya talks and eats.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: It’s basically about cultural identity as it relates to women’s rights and how one of the sad legacies of colonialism... Brad continues to listen, mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He felt a long-dormant stirring. He wanted to possess her - her energy, her passion, her beauty. At moments, this longing to absorb her became almost unbearable. Brad looks pained by his train of thought. Suddenly, another student, an Asian-American, MAYA, appea at the table.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Then her friend, Maya, showed up. Ananya introduces her to them. Troy and Brad shake her ha

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: You guys, this is my friend Maya. I told her to stop by. I hope that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (enthusiastic) Of course! Please sit down. Maya?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Yeah! Thanks. How’s it going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 66

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You go to Harvard, too? Maya nods and joins them at the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Maya plays the violin.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: And what do you play?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: I play the flute. She mimics playing the flute. Brad reacts, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Brad, Ananya and Maya enjoy wine and dessert. Troy sips a Coke.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I just don’t feel like it’s my job to be the ambassador to all these Chinese students. I mean, of course I want to help them assimilate, but I don’t even speak Mandarin. What the fuck? Brad listens with a dumb grin frozen to his face.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: She was just as beautiful, just as compelling. Brad's expression transforms into visible distress. Across the table, Ananya and Maya laugh about something.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad suddenly felt a kind of grief - for all the women he would never get to love and all the lives he would never get to live. Brad catches a glimpse of himself in a reflection. He appears old.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad never felt so old. Why did time compromise everything? Was age a hard truth or a defect of perception? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 94B
dialogues.text: 95 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 67

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girls laugh even harder. Troy laughs, too. Brad tries to join in, forcing his laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, Ananya and Maya run, laughing and happy through a g park full of trees and green.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Couldn't life be constantly renewed? Couldn’t we be forever reborn in each new fleeting moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ananya and Maya raise their glasses. A smiling Brad toasts them with his glass of wine. The mo is festive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, Troy, Ananya and Maya have exited the restaurant an congregate on the street.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for dinner!

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hey - thanks for taking the time. I know Troy appreciates it.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was cool.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: We're meeting a few people at the Druid for drinks, if you guys wanna come.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (intrigued) Oh, yeah? Where’s that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 67A

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: (points) Just across the street.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (off TROY’s look) Troy has these big meetings in the morning. He needs his sleep so...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Not even for one drink? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 68

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad looks to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’m not twenty-one - I don’t think I could get in even.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, shit. That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: But you guys have fun, all right?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Oh, and we’ll see you tomorrow night at the concert.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You will?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Not you, Dad. My dad has a dinner with his friend. But I’1l be there.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Craig Fisher. Ananya fake retches at the mention of Craig’s name.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Have fun with that. Okay, well, bye!

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Bye! Nice to meet you! Ananya and Maya head across the street, giggling. Brad watches them go with a look of longing. Brad and Troy walk back to their hotel.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Seems like you wanted to go.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Just being polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad pass a DOORMAN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 68A

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy is fast asleep in his bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 97 98 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 69

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad, in the other bed, is still in his clothes, on his laptop. He looks over at Troy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (softly) Troy? You awake? Troy? No response. Brad puts down the laptop and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad steps off the elevator and crosses toward the exit. He stands in the lobby, having second thoughts. He shakes them off and heads out, passing the same Doorma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ananya, Maya and a few other STUDENTS are drinking at a booth. The Bar is crowded. Brad watches them, from the bar, looking awkward. He turns and calls out to the BARTENDER.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I think I’m just gonna close out my tab!

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Just the whiskey? Eight dollars. Brad takes out his wallet and pulls out a TEN. He drops t bill on the bar and turns, startled to see... ..-Ananya has approached. She gives him a cheery smile.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Hey! You made it!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hey - I was having a little insomnia so I just got a whiskey!

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: We're over in the corner! Come join us! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 70 98

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Ah, nah, that’s okay! You guys are having fun! I just couldn’t sleep!

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! We’re not having fun - we're organizing a protest!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Are you really?!

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Kind of! To protect need-blind admissions!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? A protest?! Ananya looks a little buzzed. She puts her arm around him

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Everyone at that table is a future do-gooder! Like you!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah? That’s cool. I’m really impressed by you.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah - it’s cool to meet someone your age who’s so aware of what’s going on - but you’re also hopeful - and your values seem to be in the right place and...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It reminds me of when I was your age and going to school and...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: So what's your advice to me?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: My advice? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29,

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Yeah! If you could go back in time and give yourself advice - what would you say?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Seriously? Honestly?! 2016- Page 70A 98 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 71

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Yes, honestly. I’d love to know.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Honestly? I’d say, forget non- profits, Brad. And just go make a lot of money! He sorta laughs. Ananya looks quizzical.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Shut up! Are you serious?!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m serious! If you want to make an impact in this world - and have respect - go be Bill Gates! Go make a lot of money - then do good stuff with it!

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: (grimacing) That’s what you would say?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Look, I go to a dinner party - and I tell people what I do - and for about three minutes, they act like they admire me and they’re interested - and then after three minutes, I’m invisible! They don’t admire me - and worse, they think I’m gonna ask them for a donation! And sometimes I do! Ananya’s eyes narrow. He can tell he’s losing her.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What? Do I sound jaded? Just know I started out as idealistic as you or any of your friends! Believe me! Close on Ananya, listening, with an attitude. Then on Brad, talking a mile-a-minute, gesticulating. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 99 100 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 72

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad’s voice fades under the VOICE of the NARRATOR.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad could tell he had lost Ananya - lost her respect - and he desperately wanted it back. He thought if he could summarize the trajectory of his life - she would understand him - maybe even respect him - as someone who had lost the good fight - but had fought it nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Ananya are now seated at the bar with new drinks Brad continues talking. Ananya just listens, a blank expression on her face.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He told her about his career mistakes - his years in journalism just as the newspaper business was folding. His attempt to start a digital muckraking magazine in San Francisco but how no one wanted to read long-form pieces anymore - and how he had won a few prestigious prizes, which he rattled off - but his magazine still had gone bust. As Brad spews, Ananya takes a big GULP from her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ananya and Brad sit at the booth with her friends. As May and the other STUDENTS laugh and chat, Brad continues to monologue his life story for Ananya.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He talked about Craig Fisher and his other college friends and how they had sold out and gotten rich and how they didn’t even invite him to their milestone events anymore even though he had been the heart and soul of their group. Brad may have failed in their eyes, but at least he still had his integrity and could sleep at night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 73

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ananya just listens - but we sense she is judging him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar has almost emptied. Maya and the other Students a gone. Brad and Ananya are the only ones left at their boo Brad has not stopped talking.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And even though his consulting non- profit had been struggling lately - he still felt he had done some real good with it.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Maybe if I were more in the field - and really meeting more of the people that we’re helping - but I just feel kind of disconnected... On Ananya - she is silent, but there’s visible contempt i her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Ananya just listened, saying nothing, taking him in. Finally, Brad became so self-conscious, he couldn’t stand it anymore. Brad, suddenly embarrassed, blurts...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What is that look?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What are you thinking? Please tell me.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: I’m thinking... you’re lucky. You're fifty years old and you still think the world was made for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m forty-seven. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13,

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: It’s like you're mad because you don't like your position in the ruling class. Most people don’t even have a position. Most people can’t even get in the door to see what’s inside. Do you even know poor people?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: When I visit my mother’s family in Delhi, a lot of people there live on two dollars a day.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Right, I get that...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: They don’t complain about being ignored at dinner parties. They’re happy they get dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Right - but I’m not competing with those people. You compete with the people who are your markers in life.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Why are you competing at all?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It’s the way this world is.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: From my point of view - you competing with your friends from college? That competition is the history of colonialism, okay? And the oppression of women - and the fucking up of the environment...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Look, don’t go there, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Stop competing already. The future of the world depends on it... 2016 - Page 74 101 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 102 103 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 75

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (talking over her) I’m not the problem, all right? I work for a non-profit for fuck’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Sounds like you just kinda backed into it ‘cause nothing else worked out. Brad is momentarily silent, stung.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: That’s not nice.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: (softens) Sorry. It’s just - from where I sit, it kinda sounds like white privilege, male privilege, first- class problems.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Maybe I seem like a cliche to you - but this is my life, you know?

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: (nods) Just don’t ask me to feel bad for you. You're doing fine. Trust me. I promise you. You have enough. I’m going to use the rest room. She rises and walks off. Brad takes out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ananya walks across the street and disappears into the darkness. A forlorn Brad stands on the corner, watching her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, now in his underwear, quietly crawls into bed. MOONLIGHT illuminates the room. Troy is still asleep in the other bed. He doesn’t stir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 75A

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad lies in bed and stares up at the balcony doors. A dr of wind pushes the curtains and creates a whistling noise (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 104 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 76

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad knew he had blown it. He could have gotten the validation he needed from this girl, but had gone about it the wrong way. He was too honest, too open. Nobody wanted that. That was never attractive. The story of his life. Brad rolls over in bed. He sees... ..-Ananya, lying in the next bed, smiling, warmly at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: You're amazing. They share a warm smile. She waves him toward her. Suddenly, Maya appears, popping up on the other side of h

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Totally. Maya leans in and kisses Brad on the lips. Alone in bed, Brad's eyes are closed - he kisses the air, fantasizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on BRAD - even though he is asleep, there is a year expression on his face. Troy, in a towel, stands over him.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad! Brad rouses - rubbing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: We gotta go. I have my meeting.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Ugh. I’m hung-over.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Why? You only had one glass of wine. Brad says nothing. Troy heads into the bathroom.  105 106 107 108 109 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy cross the Harvard Bridge toward Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad waits on a bench for Troy to get out of his meeting. Brad is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The next morning, Brad turned on Ananya. He kept replaying in his mind things she had said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ananya, at the booth...

dialogues.speaker: ANANYA
dialogues.text: Sounds like you just kinda backed into it ‘cause nothing else worked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad grimaces at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Youth can be so arrogant and unforgiving. He doubted she would ever live up to her own lofty ideals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on ANANYA, smiling with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He could identify a strain of superiority in her. He bet if her circumstances were different, she would be singing another tune. We PULL BACK TO REVEAL Ananya on a private plane with Jas Hatfield. Maya is here, too. They all hold flutes of champagne and toast each other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 78

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: One taste of luxury - and how quickly she might forget the suffering of the masses. They guzzle down their champagne, toss their flutes to th floor and LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad shakes his head at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad realized he was just trying to make himself feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ananya, talking at dinner, full of passion.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Ananya had a good heart - she seemed wise. Brad smiles at her from across the table.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: She reminded him a lot of Melanie. Melanie has replaced Ananya. She talks animatedly, lookin radiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This latest thought causes Brad to snap out of his reveri

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Melanie. Shit. Brad takes out his PHONE and calls Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, hon. Trip’s going great. Troy is meeting with one of the music professors here right now and then he’s got an interview with the Dean of Admissions. So yeah - it all seems to be working out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, exiting a building. Brad spots...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Anyway, Troy’s here now so call me back later. I’ve got dinner with Craig Fisher... (sarcastic) -+-Sso I’m really looking forward to that, as you can imagine. Love you, honey. Brad hangs up and puts away his phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Good. He listened to some of my stuff and I think he liked it.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: That’s awesome, Troy!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: He said he was gonna put in a call to the admissions department, too.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What?! See! There you go! Connections and talent. I give you the lay up - you swish it in. Troy nods and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy walk along the campus.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You seem a little... you should be pumped! You should be happy! 2016 - Page 79 112 .-Troy and an African-American professor, JEROME BACKALY, Troy and the Professor shake hands. The Professor returns inside as Troy heads toward his dad (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 80

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Iam. I dunno. He just wasn’t what I expected. But he was fine.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: How was he not what you expected?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It was just weird - it’s like he’s one of my heroes, but he was trying kinda hard to impress me. He was sorta bragging a lot. He was more into the business side of things, too, than I would have thought. He kept telling me ways I should monetize my music - weird stuff like that. (shrugs) I thought he’d be cooler.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Uh-hunh. They continue walking in silence. Then Brad stops.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You know, don’t be so judgmental, Troy.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hunh?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You've been living in a bubble. Remember that. Do me a favor and don’t judge people who live in the real world until you've been out there yourself. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You asked me a question. I just said he wasn’t what I expected.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You said he wasn’t cool. But what’s cool to a seventeen year old hipster who doesn’t pay his own bills isn’t necessarily cool to the rest of the world.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Okay! Jesus! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 114 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 81

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Let’s talk in thirty years - and then you can tell me who’s cool!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You're fucking nuts, you know that? I’m about to have my interview - do you really need to jump all over me?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (back pedals) Troy. You're right. I’m sorry. I love you. (beat) You're the best. You’re the best son in the world - you know I think that. And you’re gonna kill it in there. Troy lets out a little laugh, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad, can you just leave me alone? I’m gonna go clear my head. I/11 meet you after. All right?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Okay. Good idea. Yeah. As Troy walks toward the ADMISSIONS OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Proud of you, Troy! Troy just keeps walking and enters the building. Brad stands on the lawn, unsure of what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad sits with another FATHER in the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Was that your daughter? (off FATHER’s nod) She have an interview now?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I hope it goes well. (beat) My son is meeting with the Dean so he’s been a little on edge.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Good luck. Brad’s PHONE RINGS. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason Hatfield is on the other end of the line. He paces hall, wearing a suit.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Hey, Brad. It’s Jason Hatfield. Intercut phone call:

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Jason! Hey! What’s up? Brad rises and quickly exits the ADMISSIONS OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad has moved to the corner of the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Uh, my office said you called me.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Oh, right. I was actually just calling for Craig's number, but I got it from Billy.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Okay, good. All right, well...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I heard you guys all got together in LA. How was that?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Listen, man, I can’t really talk - I got a lot going on right now. 82 114 the (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 83

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (little laugh) Oh, okay. Well...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t mean to be rude, but I got all these clients looking for me. And I’m in Minnesota - at the Mayo Clinic to get these test results - but if I don’t get ona flight to New York by noon, I’m gonna miss this deposition I’ve been preparing for for months...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Okay. I hear ya. At least you know the plane will wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Don’t you have your own jet? Must make it a little easier...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Jet? Are you being an asshole right now or...?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (thrown) What? No. I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t have a jet. What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I thought... I swear you told me once you had a private plane.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: In San Francisco, when I saw you - you said you were just on your...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: My company leased a plane to get everyone out there, but... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 84

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, I misunderstood...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Look, I just found out my daughter has a tethered spine, okay? She’s fucking three years old.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (attitude shifting) What? Oh, no. Man, Jason! What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it means - except she has to have major surgery tomorrow morning. She’s so little. Jason sounds like he’s about to start crying.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It’s killing me...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Shit. Is she okay?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I think so. It’s... I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do? I’ve worked with a lot of children’s hospitals with my...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: We're sitting down with the doctors now. I gotta go, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (genuine) Okay, Jason - keep me posted. And please give my love to your family. I’m really sorry... The phone goes dead. Brad looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy returns from his interview to find... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 85

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: «+-a contemplative Brad, sitting in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: 116A
dialogues.text: Seeing Troy, Brad rises and gives him a heartfelt embrace He clutches Troy tight - smelling his hair. The other PARENTS and STUDENTS turn. Troy is thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy and Brad exit the campus toward Harvard Square.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Well, aren’t you gonna even ask me how it went? Brad stops and turns.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Right, right. Yeah! How’d it go?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (grins) Really good. He said Jerome Backaly already called him - and told him I was talented and to pay attention to my application. Isn’t that awesome?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: That’s great, Troy! Awesome! I knew you would! Brad gives Troy a big high-five. Troy grins. Brad then hails down a passing TAXI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy sit in silence in the back of the cab. smiling to himself. He looks over and notices Brad’s uneasy expression.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Troy, I don’t want to like lay a trip on you but... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 Troy is (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 86

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRAD (cont'd) just so you know - if anything bad ever happened - to you - whatever capacity I have left to feel joy... Brad is about to choke up. He then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Only good things are gonna happen to you. Only good things. Brad musters a sweet smile. Troy looks at his dad, slightly concerned, then turns to window - his smile soon returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy walk up the stairs of the Admissions Buildi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy approach the RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hey - I’m Brad Sloan and this is my son, Troy. He had an interview this morning - but we, uh, had to miss it, unfortunately. Is there any way he could still sit with somebody?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (looks at computer) I’m not sure...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m an alumni, actually. Class of “90.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: And a donor. Troy covers his face, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’1l have to check the schedule. I’1l do my best. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 87

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They step away from the desk. Brad turns to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Thank you. Go Jumbos.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Meanwhile our next tour is about to leave, if you’d like to join...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Okay, cool.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hey, Troy - while you’re on the tour - I might go visit one of my old professors.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He was like my mentor - I told you about him.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Do it. Go.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It seems like you’re eager to get rid of me.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (smiles amused) Are you embarrassed of me? You embarrassed of your dad?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (smiles, sheepishly) Me? No. Never.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, it seems like it. You think I’m gonna make a scene or something? (off TROY’S head shake) I would never intentionally embarrass you.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Good. Thanks. 120 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 87A

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad smiles and gives Troy a kiss on the forehead, then h out. As he goes, he calls out to the ADMISSIONS STAFF.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (points to TROY) You have a legacy here, people! And a genius! F.Y.I.! Brad gives Troy a mischievous wink, then exits the buildi Troy flushes red, shaking his head.  BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 88

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad scans the DIRECTORY OF OFFICES by the entrance. He finds - “Professor Connor - Room 107”. Brad heads off, down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad approaches Room 107 and peers inside. The office see to be in transition. There are moving boxes on the shelve and on the floor. A FEMALE PROFESSOR - around Brad's age - is at the desk. looks up from her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Uh, hi. I’m an old student of Professor Connor’s. I was hoping to see him. Is he...?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Oh, you just missed him.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He just left?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: No. I’m sorry to say, he died. Just a few weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He did? His name’s still on the... directory.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I know - we need to change that. I just got in here.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: How did he... die?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: He had a stroke. And he never recovered.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s sad.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 123 124 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 89

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He was a great teacher.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: He was a sweet man.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Well, have a nice day.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Thanks. You, too. Brad heads out. The Professor returns to her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad wanders the campus, lost in thought. After a moment, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad thought about the events of the morning and felt a sudden clarity. How ridiculous it was for him to be jealous - or insecure about his place. Brad watches TWO STUDENTS - a young, attractive couple - past, holding hands. They are in love.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: What a waste of energy to resent other people’s few pleasures. Brad watches them go. A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN, looking harried and stressed, is nex approach.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: How stingy and mean - when everyone struggles. Brad gives her a consoling smile, as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distressed Jason Hatfield sits in a hallway, waiting fo news. His Wife can be seen, talking to a DOCTOR in the b. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 125 126 127 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 90

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He pictured his friends in their private, anxious moments. No one is immune to pain. Jason nervously cracks his knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad walks, then stops to look at... .+.a MEMORIAL PLAQUE, commemorating a departed University President.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad’s thoughts then turned to death. The great equalizer. Brad studies the memorial, closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIPLOMAS and DEGREES for “ROBERT CONNOR” have been placed into various boxes on the shelves to be taken away. In one box, we SEE a PHOTO of the distinguished, old PROFESSOR shaking some important person’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His professor gone - without a trace - a brilliant man with a unique mind - and at the institution he had given his whole life to - already replaced. We SEE now the Female Professor - she types blithely away her computer. INT. BRAD’S PARENTS’ HOUSE - OFFICE - DAY 127 A HOSPICE NURSE tends to Brad’s dying dad.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He imagined the moment his father would die - and what his legacy would vanish. On a nearby couch, Melanie holds Brad’s hand in hers, comforting him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 128 129 130 131 132 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 91

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: No money can keep you alive forever - no status. CLOSE on Brad’s dad - his last breath is expired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, deep in thought, sits on the stairs outside the Admission Office.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Brad wondered which friend of his would die first. EXT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 129 The after-party for Nick's wedding. A gorgeous sunset. We SEE Billy Werstler, drinking with his TWO GIRLFRIENDS. INT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 130 Craig and Diane have a spirited debate in the kitchen. Nearby, Jason and his Wife corral their Kids, preparing t leave. EXT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 131 Nick and his Husband share a sweet kiss by the wedding ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, looking wistful, still sits on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Life itself is the pleasure, Brad thought. The only real pleasure. Brad looks out... A GROUP OF MALE TUFTS STUDENTS are congregated under a tr teasing each other and laughing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 132 133 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 92

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In an important time in their lives, Brad and his friends had shared this pleasure together - and what a beautiful, profound thing. Brad smiles at the sight. He continues to watch them.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Something felt changed in Brad - he felt he would never see things the same again. Brad looks over... ...the COLLEGE TOUR is returning. Troy is among the group He gives Brad a half-wave. Brad rises and waves back, smiling. Then his CELL PHONE BUZZES. He takes out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie, on her cell phone, has stepped away from some CO WORKERS.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Brad - hey. I saw you called. Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (into phone) Everything's great. Yeah. It’s great. Mel?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I just... isn’t it crazy? You and me - we made this kid and now he’s this brilliant, amazing person and... (chokes up) I wish you were here.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Awww. So do I. Well, honey, we’re about to go into the conference. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133 134 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 93

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MELANIE (cont'd) I should probably go. I love you. I‘11 call you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, great. I love you, too. Brad hangs up and looks back over at... ...Troy, shaking hands with the TOUR GUIDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy are getting dressed to go out.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I liked Tufts. It’s a good school. I’d be happy there. You went there. (turns to BRAD) Thanks for bringing me here, Dad. And, you know, going all out and everything.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Ah, I didn’t do anything.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You made all those calls. And now you have to go to dinner with a guy you hate.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I don’t hate him. I like him.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You said he was a jerk and you hated his guts.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Nah, he’s a good guy. He’s an old friend. I’m looking forward to seeing him, actually. Old friends are important. Brad pats a confused Troy on the back as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: K. I’m heading out. See you after your concert!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Bye! Have fun! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 134 135 136 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 94

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad exits, leaving Troy alone. EXT. AZALIA’S - NIGHT 135 Brad enters the crowded, fancy restaurant. INT. AZALIA’S - CONTINUOUS 136 Brad approaches the HOSTESS.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Hi. I believe I have a reservation. It’s for two at seven. The name’s Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Okay, yeah. You’re the first to arrive. Would you like to wait at the bar or go ahead to the table?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I think - just go to the table. The Hostess leads him toward a small table - right by the bar. PATRONS mill around. It’s loud.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but is there another table? It’s just really loud right here...

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: We're fully booked tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, what about that table? Brad points to a bigger, empty table in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but it’s not available.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It looks available.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Yeah - it’s not. Brad nods, giving up. He sits at the little table.  137 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 95 INT. AZALIA’S - MOMENTS LATER 137 Brad is getting jostled by BAR PATRONS. He looks annoyed. He spots Craig... who enters the restaurant and approache the Hostess. She greets him, warmly. The Hostess leads Craig over to Brad's table.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (rising) Hey, man! Craig and Brad share a bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Look at you. You look good!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Ah, I'm going gray!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Not as bad as me!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I know - we failed in life!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: We failed to stay young! Hey, grab your beer - we’re moving tables!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We are?! Oh, cool!

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Brad and Craig have been seated at the quiet table in the corner. The Hostess hands Brad a menu.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: So I guess this table was available.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: (perfunctory smile) Yes. Enjoy your dinner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 95A

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 137 The Hostess locks eyes with Craig, as she hands him a men

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming tonight. We love having you! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 96

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Can I get a Jack and Coke?

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Absolutely! I/’11 get that for you! The Hostess departs.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You must be a regular.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Never been here before. I hear it’s good though.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Really? She was acting like you guys were best friends. Craig shrugs, faux-modestly.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, so she just recognizes you. (off CRAIG’s look) Must be nice. (beat; smiles) Dude! How long’s it been?!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Must be over ten years!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah! I’m so glad to see you, man! (meaningful) I’m really glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m glad to see you, pal. Welcome to Boston. Where you staying?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: We're at the Oak Tree Execustay.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (makes a face) I don’t think I’ve ever heard of anyone staying there. Is it nice? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The HOSTESS brings Craig’s drink and sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It’s not bad. Listen, thank you so much for getting Troy in to see that music professor and the Dean of Admissions. That’s huge. He had great meetings.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m glad. Can’t believe he’s already looking at colleges.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Me either!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, I guess my girls are, too. They're only twelve and they’re all over it. Already filling out applications. They’re so much more on it than we were.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Troy's got a great attitude about it all.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Is he medicated?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So how’s Melanie?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: She's great. She likes her job. She’s always been pretty happy.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Diane just sold an article to HBO. They’re gonna make a series out of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh. Cool. (beat) So we went to Tufts today. Bob Connor died.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I know, I know. 2016 - Page 97 137 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13,

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You knew?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I spoke at his memorial.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’d been in touch. He'd asked me to come speak at his class a few times about journalism and government...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (slightly stung) He did, hunh? That’s flattering.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I try to get out of stuff like that - but for him. Such a great person.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah. He was the closest thing I had to a mentor.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I remember. You were his favorite. At the time.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I wish I'd been there at his memorial. I wish I’d known.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: If I'd seen you at Nick’s wedding, I would have told you about it - it happened right after...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, I didn’t know about Nick’s thing either.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You didn’t miss much. Nick’s gotten so... I mean, I love the guy. But the more successful he gets, the gayer he gets. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2016 - Page 98 137 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 99

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CRAIG (cont'd) He’s now like a full-on flamer - with hairless dudes in banana hammocks running around his house, humping each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I saw his house in an Architectural Digest.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s like a set for a sci-fi gay porno or something.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I talked to Jason today.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah? How’s he?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, he sounded stressed. His kid is sick. I think she has something wrong with her spine.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That sucks. Which one? He has like four.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I think I might have offended him. I thought he had his own jet for some reason - and I brought it up - maybe I sounded glib - I don’t know. But he seemed annoyed that I accused him of having his own plane. I felt bad.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He does have a plane.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No, he doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yes, he does.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No. His company maybe leases one.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, his company. That's his company. That’s his plane. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 100

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Didn't you read the piece in the Times? (off BRAD’s blank look) He’s getting sued. He lost a lot of money for a lot of powerful people. He’s running scared. And there was this brutal take-down piece in the Times - actually written by a friend of mine - which put me in a really awkward position. It talked about his lavish lifestyles - the houses in the Hamptons - the private planes.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Might be why he was a little sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought... I got it all wrong, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Jason's a pillar of society. He’s a family man. He’s a good dude. And he’s a total crook. Craig laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He’s a thief. And there’s a chance - albeit slight - he goes to jail.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Jesus. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: In his business - you don’t want to stay at the tables too long. Get your money. And then get the fuck out. ‘Cause somewhere along the line, you probably did something shady. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 101

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CRAIG (cont'd) You don’t get rich like that by being an Eagle Scout. He should do what Billy did. Flee.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Right. Billy really seems to be living the dream. Two girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Just don’t call him after 5pm.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What do you mean? He’s a drunk.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He is?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah - and a... (pantomimes snorting coke) And a... Craig pantomimes injecting his arm with heroin.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Don’t be naive. You knew that.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: When we talked on the phone, he sounded okay. He was like walking his dog early in the morning...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He’d probably been up all night on a bender. In his defense, he’s got a lot of time on his hands. You pick up vices.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m so in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That’s what happens when you drop out and move to Sacramento. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 102

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I moved to Sacramento. I didn’t drop out.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Why did you move to Sacramento?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Melanie got a job there. And I can work anywhere right now.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, right - with your little... thing. That’s a cool thing you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (stung) Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Good stuff. I’m sorry I never got back to you about that.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It just came at a moment when I was getting bombarded. It’s like every day I get hit up with requests. Speaking engagements, writing introductions to someone’s book... (points to BRAD) .--asking to be put on boards, executive boards, non-profit boards. There’s just not enough time in the day - sometimes you’ve gotta just draw the line. As hard as it is - you just have to learn how to say no. Yesterday, I got asked to speak at the Aspen Ideas Festival in June. Well, that I’m going to do. That’s cool, you know? Interesting people, well curated...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Listen - Craig - I just want to say - I’m proud of you. I really am. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 103

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRAD (cont'd) I mean, I know it must be pretty stressful to have so many balls in the air and have so much going on, but from the outside...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Not that stressful. It’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Well, I’m just happy for you. To be honest, at first, I'd see you on TV - and it kind of... bothered me - just because we always had a little competitive thing going. But I’m happy with my life - and you’re doing what you want to do - things work out the way they should. Craig nods - then furrows his brow.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I was never competitive with you. Brad takes a beat, his eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. Really?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Maybe in school for like a second. But I haven’t thought of you in that way for years.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It means... I dunno. Why would I compete with you?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Oh, shut the fuck up. Craig looks at Brad with a perplexed grin.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What? Brad is suddenly defensive. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 104 137

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I just... I’m trying to be real with you. I mean, it’s like... what is your deal?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Suddenly, they are approached by a YOUNG MALE STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Fisher. My name’s Mark - and I'm a big fan of yours. I love your books and everything you do...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Like do you know what I do? I actually help people. And like - I dunno - like why would you treat me like this?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Treat you like what?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: What am I to you? Hunh?

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Am I interrupting?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Is it possible to get a picture?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: My mother died - you never said anything, man. Like - you follow me on Facebook. I... I dunno. I just don’t know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  137 138 139 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 105

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m confused. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Are you my friend? You know? Are we even... what are we? All the shit-talking. Like right now I’m feeling like... I just know what I'm feeling and it’s not... Brad rises from the table.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What the fuck? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Thanks for helping my son. But it’s like... I’m just done - with this. Whatever this is. Brad takes a TWENTY from his pocket and sets it on the ta Brad turns and walks to the exit, in a hurry. Craig and the Male Student, mouths agape, watch him go. EXT. AZALIA’S - NIGHT 138 Brad exits the restaurant and lets out a long EXHALE. He rubs his fingers through his hair, shakes his head. Wo case scenario. Then walks off, into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Brad - as he heads toward the CONCERT HALL.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The entire walk, Brad could only think about what Craig's take-away would be - and what he would tell everyone. eH FH  F HHH HHH HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 141 142 143 144 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 106 INT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 140 Craig regales his wife, Diane and a few other GUESTS.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It was embarrassing. He’s out of his mind. He’s completely lost it. INT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 141 Craig talks to Nick and Nick’s Husband.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He was the golden boy in college - and now I’m the one who’s winning prizes and getting recognized. He’s overcome with jealousy. INT. NICK PASCALE’S HOUSE - DAY 142 Craig chats with Jason and his Wife.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He’s insane. He’s a pedophile. He looks old. Jason and his Wife, nod, solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad crosses the quad to the concert hall.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Why did he let Craig get to him? After all these years, why didn’t Brad have a stronger sense of self? Why couldn’t he sustain a feeling about himself? Or even a point of view?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad stands at the BOX OFFICE, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Why was he always elsewhere, in his head, puffing himself up or tearing himself down? Enough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145 BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 107

dialogues.speaker: TICKET SELLER
dialogues.text: Sir. Your ticket. Brad snaps out of it. He takes his ticket and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small concert hall, mostly filled. Brad stands at the back, looking for Troy. He spots him, sitting alone, near the front.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Brad appears by Troy’s side.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (surprised) Dad? Brad gives Troy a smile and takes the seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What about your dinner?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I'd rather be with you. Troy nods - as the AUDITORIUM LIGHTS GO DOWN. The LIGHTS GO UP on the stage - a group of about THIRTY STUDENT MUSICIANS are seated. Then, Ananya, with her flute, and Maya, with her violin, onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Those are the girls from last night.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I know. The musicians begin to play DVORAK’S “HUMORESQUE”. The music is beautiful, soothing, smooth. ON BRAD - as he listens, lost in thought. Brad looks over at... Troy, sitting still beside him, enjoying the music. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page 108

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad takes Troy in with a proud, melancholy smile. He then turns his attention to the stage. ON STAGE - Ananya, on her flute, and Maya, on her violin, playing their duet. ON BRAD - as he listens, he looks increasingly stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (loud whisper) They’re so good.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Shh. Dad. Brad sits back in his seat, taking it in, really listenin

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The music is beautiful, Brad thought. The concert continues. Ananya and Maya are extraordinarily talented.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: These girls are beautiful. ON BRAD - he is visibly moved.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He could love them and never possess them. The entire orchestra joins in - the music is gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Just like he could love the world and never possess it. A dam of emotion bursts. Brad is now crying in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He still did love the world. Deep, cathartic tears. Troy looks over and sees that his father is crying.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Dad? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 146 147 BRAD'S STATUS - Pink Revision - Sept. 29, 2016- Page 109

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad tries to get a handle on his emotions. He wipes his eyes and smiles reassuringly to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I’m okay. Brad looks back toward the orchestra. He begins to become emotional again.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The very last moments of the performance. The musicians finish. It’s over. The audience begins to politely CLAP. Brad just sits there, spent. He starts to CLAP, too. In deep appreciation. We HOLD on Brad and Troy clapping for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Troy walk in silence back to their hotel. We HEA the noise of the passing CARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad is emotionally spent. He sits on the bed, still in h dinner clothes, exhausted. Troy is checking out the MINI-BAR. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - WHITE VERSION - Sept 13, 2016 - Page

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You want some chips? Brad shakes his head. Troy watches him for a second.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Ananya said you met up with her last night. Brad looks up, sharply.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, I couldn’t sleep. It was just a drink.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (nods) Dad. Are you having some kind of nervous breakdown or something? Brad looks at Troy and lets out an amused exhale.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: No. (beat) It’s just... sometimes I have doubts. I worry that people look at me - and think of me as a failure. (shrugs) But the feeling passes. Brad gives Troy a strained smile. 110 147 Troy opens a bag of chips and sits down beside Brad on th bed.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: When we were walking around today and you were embarrassing me - I kept thinking - if I go to this school, everyone here is gonna remember this. I’1l never be able to live this down. (little laugh) But they won’t remember. They’re just thinking about themselves, you know? Nobody cares. The only person thinking about you is me. So the only opinion that should matter to you is mine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 148 149 150 BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 111

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad turns to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah. And what’s your opinion?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) I love you. Brad's eyes instantly fill with emotion. Brad nods, accepting this.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (softly) Thank you. Brad looks at his son with gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights in the room are out. MOONLIGHT illuminates the room. Brad, in bed, looks over at Troy, sound asleep. Brad then looks up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: That night, a memory popped into Brad’s head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic hour. We SEE a group of YOUNG MALE STUDENTS, from a short distance away, gathering on the quad lawn. They are CHATTING and LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He and his friends were back in college. They were on the quad, laughing about something. They were still young - all potential - unformed and undefined. We STAY on this image for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON BRAD - lost in his memory. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRAD'S STATUS - Blue Revision - Sept 26, 2016 - Page 112

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Brad stares at the balcony doors. A draft of wind blows t curtains slightly. We HEAR a faint whistling noise.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: A sudden rush of feeling flooded Brad. He lay there a while, letting himself really feel the life inside him. He kept saying in his mind - I’m alive. I’m alive. I’m still alive. Brad smiles to himself rolling over on his side, turning from us - we HEAR the beginning of Dvorak’s “Humoresque” we... FADE TO BLACK.
